G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s refusal to remedy the defect constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in all residential leases pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and recognized under Massachusetts common law.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, and Massachusetts case law, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, guaranteeing tenants the right to use and enjoy the premises free from substantial interference caused by the landlord or persons acting under the landlord’s control.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14, identifies it as the “quiet enjoyment” statute, and explains that it protects tenants from serious interference with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions or by conditions the landlord permits to exist. The court holds that a landlord may be liable under § 14 where, by failing to act against unlawful drug activity by others on the premises, it permits a condition that seriously interferes with tenants’ use and enjoyment of common areas. This aligns with the proposition that every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting against substantial interference caused by the landlord or persons/conditions under the landlord’s control.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished… The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: Defendant’s inaction has deprived Plaintiff of the full and comfortable use of her rental unit, forcing her to endure the loss of livable space and health hazards in violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that the landlord’s repeated failure to correct flooding and sewage problems, despite notice, breached duties under the warranty of habitability and constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court specifically characterizes Gem’s wrongdoing as an ‘outrageous omission to act’ that allowed repeated flooding which impaired Solomon’s use of her apartment and created unsanitary, harmful conditions. That reasoning supports the proposition that a landlord’s inaction depriving a tenant of full, comfortable, and healthful use of the rental unit violates the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent… The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Gem violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment… it could be found that Gem violated its duty to Solomon recklessly, by outrageous omission to act.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s actions, Plaintiff has suffered damages, including but not limited to the loss of use of her Apartment, property damage, and health concerns.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a violation of the Massachusetts lead paint statute, by itself, constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and what level of landlord fault (at least negligence with notice) is required. It does not discuss or establish any rule about the types of damages a plaintiff may recover, such as loss of use of an apartment, property damage, or health concerns. Although the case mentions that the plaintiffs suffered lead poisoning and recovered compensatory damages, it does not set out a legal principle on damages that would support the specific proposition cited.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “In response to special questions, the jury found that lead paint on the premises was the proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ injuries, and awarded $25,000 in compensatory damages to Dina and $10,000 in compensatory damages to Husam. … On appeal, the landlords do not dispute that the apartment contained lead paint, or that the plaintiffs’ lead poisoning was proximately caused by the lead in the apartment… The only question is whether on this record the plaintiffs were entitled to recover attorney’s fees under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

App..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landlord-tenant summary process action, focusing on the propriety of a stay of execution and the landlord’s entitlement to use and occupancy payments from a tenant at sufferance. It does not address or analyze damages such as loss of use of an apartment, property damage, or health concerns suffered by a plaintiff as a direct and proximate result of a defendant’s actions. Thus, it does not provide authority for the causation-and-damages proposition stated.
*Armstrong v. Collella*, 2001 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “Upon the termination of his tenancy at will by the landlord’s notice to quit, the defendant-tenant remained on the premises as a tenant at sufferance… with a legal obligation to pay for his use and occupation of those premises. G.L. c. 186, §3. The tenant remains liable even in those cases in which a valid stay of execution is ordered. The plaintiff-landlord is entitled to recover such payments in this case…”
